Award.AwardTitle: Activities of the Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mission of the Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate (BASC) is to provide independent assistance to Federal agencies and the Nation on issues in the atmospheric and climate sciences. The BASC strives to advance understanding of atmospheric science, meteorology, and climate; foster application of this knowledge to benefit the public; help ensure that U.S. research programs are responsive to scientific opportunities and the needs of the Nation; and help make scientific information more useful in government planning and decision-making.

The BASC has worked extensively to ensure discussion of climate issues remained visible. For 2008-2011, it will continue to plan activities where objective, independent discussion and analysis are needed. Areas include severe weather, scientific understanding of climate change and impacts (especially at different scales), observation systems, and additional topics as requested. The BASC will seek opportunities to use its role as a neutral, independent body to encourage open discussion of issues.

Using an extensive network of volunteers, the BASC brings diverse scientific perspectives together in service to national needs. BASC strives to enhance understanding of atmosphere and climate, provide independent views on U.S. research efforts, and ensure that experts are involved in government decision-making. The Board is able to ask the "best and brightest" to volunteer their time and these volunteers are the intellectual force behind all the Board's work. Participants are selected to bring a diversity of expertise and experience; they are broad thinkers who can both react to requests for assistance and look ahead to anticipate issues. The Board has a reputation for objectivity, careful analysis, and commitment to our fields of science. Based on the rigorous processes of the National Academies, the BASC provides information of value to both the science community and government decision makers.

The BASC does not conduct primary research, but works instead to ensure that the atmospheric and climate sciences have broad impact on society. Through its work, the BASC increases understanding of issues at the forefront of national discussion. Understanding of these issues directly affects the Nation's environmental policies, energy choices, manufacturing decisions, construction codes, agricultural methods, and even human health. The BASC activities serve the science community, federal and state decision makers, educators, and the public and are disseminated widely. Activities involve a diverse range of people, with thought given to gender, ethnicity, age, geography, and institutional diversity.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate

Review period: 07/01/2011-12/31/2011

  The Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate (BASC or Board) is the center within the National Academies for activities related to the atmospheric and climate sciences, technology, and related services. Through board meetings, study committees, and other activities, BASC strives to advance understanding of atmospheric science, meteorology, and climate and supporting technologies; foster application of this knowledge to benefit the public and decision makers; advise U.S. research programs so they are responsive to scientific opportunities and the needs of the nation; and ensure that government decision making benefits from independent scientific input. Activities include discussion forums, program reviews; assistance in identifying research opportunities; evaluation of relevant technologies; analyses of controversial and nationally important topics; and other tasks. BASC does not conduct research, but works to give research a broader impact on society, both in the United States and internationally.

 BASC designs its activities to respond to the needs of its agency partners. BASC’s interests span a range of topics within the general areas of atmospheric science, climate science, and meteorology and deal with both the research dimensions and services associated with these fields. Areas of emphasis include:

  • increasing our understanding of climate variability and change,
  • improving methods to assess and predict climate variability, change, and impacts,
  • optimization of weather observation and forecasting systems for different purposes,
  • optimization of communication of weather and climate information,
  • atmospheric composition and chemistry and related issues, including transport of air pollution,
  • advancement of prediction capabilities for weather, space weather, and climate
  • atmospheric/land/ocean interactions, and
  • improving the availability and use of atmospheric and climate science information in support of national needs.

 Board members are responsible for identifying emerging issues, strategic planning, information-gathering, interactions with agencies and scientists, program oversight, new initiatives, information dissemination, and oversight of the studies. The Board meets two times each year to oversee activities, plan new activities, host discussion forums, and interact with scientists and decision-makers. In 2011, BASC held meetings June 8-9 and October 13-14 in Washington, DC. Highlights include a panel discussion on Radio Spectrum Allocation with NASA and NOAA; discussion of the NOAA/NWS Weather Ready Nations program with Kathryn Sullivan, NOAA Deputy Administrator; and discussion of the World Climate Research Program with representatives from WCRP, GEWEX, CLIVAR, CLiC and SPARC. The Board also organized a summer workshop July 27-29 on urban meteorology in Woods Hole, MA, bringing together providers and users of urban weather information.

 Ad hoc studies this year included:

  • The National Weather Service Modernization and Associated Restructuring: A Retrospective Assessment [released]
  • America’s Climate Choices (ACC) [continued dissemination]
  • Advice to the US Global Change Research Program [in process]
  • A National Strategy for Advancing Climate Modeling [in process]
  • Assessment of the National Weather Service's Modernization Program [in process]
  • Urban Meteorology: Scoping the problem, defining the needs [in process]
  • Himalayan Glaciers, Climate Change, and Implications for Downstream Populations [in process]
